paragraphs.text:
%md # Introduction to Splice Machine for Data Scientists This curriculum is recommended for data scientists and data engineers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand the topics in this section, you need to have experience with SQL, and some programming experience with Python or Scala. You should also have experience with implementing Machine Learning, data transformation, data analysis, streaming, model design and selection, and results interpretation. You can expect to spend 2-3 hours completing this curriculum. Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and most notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web. This is the sequence of notebooks in our *Splice Machine Data Scientist* class:
1. If you've not already done so, please visit our General Introduction to Splice Machine notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. And if you're new to using Zeppelin, our Introduction to Zeppelin notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this section.
3. This class starts with our Importing Data and Running Queries notebook, which introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
4. The Using Spark in Zeppelin Notebooks notebook demonstrates writing and running a Spark program in Zeppelin.
5. The Using our Native Spark DataSource notebook demonstrates how our Native Spark DataSource allows you to adopt the full power of Spark and manipulate dataframes while also having the power of full ANSI, ACID-compliant SQL.
6. The Machine Learning with Spark MLib notebook contains Python code that uses the Machine Learning Library embedded in Spark, MLlib, with the Splice Machine Spark Adapter to realize in-process machine learning.
7. The KMeans Example notebook presents an unsupervised-learning, clustering algorithm used to determine similarities and trends within a given dataset.
8. The Decision Trees Example notebook demonstrates how to load a LIBSVM data file, parse it as an RDD of LabeledPoint and then perform classification using a decision tree with Gini impurity as an impurity measure.
9. The ETL Pipeline Example notebook presents a simple example of implementing an ETL pipeline with Splice Machine.

msg.data:
Introduction to Splice Machine for Data Scientists

This curriculum is recommended for data scientists and data engineers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand the topics in this section, you need to have experience with SQL, and some programming experience with Python or Scala. You should also have experience with implementing Machine Learning, data transformation, data analysis, streaming, model design and selection, and results interpretation. You can expect to spend 2-3 hours completing this curriculum.

Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and most notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web.

This is the sequence of notebooks in our Splice Machine Data Scientist class:

1. If you've not already done so, please visit our General Introduction to Splice Machine notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. And if you're new to using Zeppelin, our Introduction to Zeppelin notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this section.
3. This class starts with our Importing Data and Running Queries notebook, which introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
4. The Using Spark in Zeppelin Notebooks notebook demonstrates writing and running a Spark program in Zeppelin.
5. The Using our Native Spark DataSource notebook demonstrates how our Native Spark DataSource allows you to adopt the full power of Spark and manipulate dataframes while also having the power of full ANSI, ACID-compliant SQL.
6. The Machine Learning with Spark MLib notebook contains Python code that uses the Machine Learning Library embedded in Spark, MLlib, with the Splice Machine Spark Adapter to realize in-process machine learning.
7. The KMeans Example notebook presents an unsupervised-learning, clustering algorithm used to determine similarities and trends within a given dataset.
8. The Decision Trees Example notebook demonstrates how to load a LIBSVM data file, parse it as an RDD of LabeledPoint and then perform classification using a decision tree with Gini impurity as an impurity measure.
9. The ETL Pipeline Example notebook presents a simple example of implementing an ETL pipeline with Splice Machine.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Where to Go Next
Please start this class with the [*Importing Data and Running Queries*](/#/notebook/2DWWYV8BB) notebook for an introduction to running Splice Machine database queries.
